GameStop presents a really interesting opportunity because it's very, very high volatility. And the options positions that we use in the strategy are both short options positions. So it means we're selling. We're selling options in something that is very high volatility. That means that you're going to make a lot more money on a relative basis compared to selling options on something with lower volatility. You're also taking advantage of some structural components of volatility, things like volatility risk premium VRP. Now, that sounds a little heavy, but it's a very simple concept. Because GameStop uniquely has exceedingly high vault salinity on the call side, rather than what you typically get in the coverage triangle on like an index ETF, the calls don't really help you that much. Because you collect a little bit on them. But there's not a lot of vault in them on a relative basis to the puts in GameStop. It's the opposite. You make a lot of money on a relative basis by selling the calls. So this is a really lucrative selling position that, again, is based on the premise that we just want to hold the stock anyways because the short puts are cash secured. So what this means is if the stock expires below my strike on the puts, there are things we can do to manage to avoid getting assigned there. We can roll out and down, which we'll probably do, all of that at some point. But you want to own the stock anyways. And this isn't like the superficial people that sell a put and they collect the premium and they say, oh, I want to buy the stock anyways. And then the stock plumets and they're like, wait a minute, I don't actually want the stock. It's, I'm beyond that.
